description: From (Northumbrian) Old English fǣra, aphetic form of ġefēra (whence also Middle English y-fere).

entries.meaning: (dialectal or obsolete) A companion, comrade or friend.
examples: they swange oute their swerdis and slowe of noble men of armys mo than an hondred – and than they rode ayen to theire ferys.

entries.meaning: (archaic) A person's spouse, or an animal's mate.
examples: The lamb rejoiceth in the year, / And raceth freely with his fere, / And answers to his mother’s calls / From the flower’d furrow.

adjectives.description: fere (comparative more fere, superlative most fere)
